question.text: Which of the following are examples of University sponsored programs that may involve children on University-owned or leased property?
The term "University Sponsored Program" as described in the Child Protection Policy is defined as
question.option: Single performances or events open to the general public that are not targeted toward children (such as varsity athletic competitions, plays, concerts)
Regularly scheduled classes or activities designed primarily for enrolled students who are age 17 and above.
Ongoing or planned events that are designed by the University to include children such as camps, lessons, workshops, clubs, teams, projects, practices, tours, or open-houses.

question.text: The participation of children requires an increased level of care and an expectation that individuals will conduct themselves appropriately.
A minor/child is defined as a person under the age of 18 who is emancipated from his or her parents.

The purpose of USI’s Child Protection Policy is to protect the safety and well-being of children who are on University-owned or leased property (both on and off campus) and/or who participate in University sponsored child-related programs.
USI’s Child Protection Policy addresses which of the following:
question.option: The roles and responsibilities of specific members within the university community
How to attain child care licensure

question.text: USI’s Child Protection Policy applies to ALL members of the university community regardless of the funding source.
Which is considered inappropriate conduct or child abuse:
question.option: Shaking a child to get his attention
Being under the influence of drugs or alcohol in the presence of children
Engaging in sexually inappropriate conduct of any kind toward or in the presence of a child
Neglecting the duty of care for a child under the adult’s supervision

question.text: Child abuse is defined as:
question.option: Serious physical, emotional, or verbal mistreatment of a child, and/or engaging in sexual activity with a child.
Physical acts which cause serious physical injury to a child
Acts likely to result in the emotional trauma of a child

Any behavior which results in touching of the sexual or other intimate parts of a child for the purpose of sexual gratification of the child and/or adult, including touching by the child and/or adult with or without clothing.

question.text: An “authorized adult” is defined as: University employees who are at least eighteen years of age and who are assigned to teach or otherwise perform work in a program as part of their official job duties, or a representative of a group that has obtained permission to use campus facilities from a University department or employee authorized to grant such permission.
The term “inappropriate conduct” is defined as “actions or omissions which do not rise to the level of child abuse, but are otherwise prohibited under USI’s Child Protection Policy.”

Being under the influence of drugs or alcohol while supervising / participating in programs involving children is an example of “inappropriate conduct” and is prohibited under the Child Protection Policy.

University sponsored programs that include ongoing or planned events that are designed to include children must ensure that all University employees, students and volunteers who will work with children have been subject to background and sex offender registry checks.
As a member of the university community, it is your duty to report any suspected child abuse or neglect to which of the following entities:
question.option: The University Director of Public Safety

question.text: Visitors to the university who have contact with children do not have to abide by this policy.
It is recommended that two “authorized adult” supervisors be present at activities involving children. In the event this is not possible, which of the following is the minimum requirement?
question.option: At least one authorized adult supervisor must be present.
Two or more unauthorized adults supervisors must be present.
One authorized adult and another adult is required.
One authorized adult and two other adults are required.

question.text: Adults must sleep in the same room as the child they are supervising.
All members of the university community, regardless of job duty or title, must do which of the following:
question.option: Engage in appropriate conduct when working with children.
Report suspected child abuse to the proper authorities.
Maintain state licenses and keep them prominently displayed.
Develop departmental procedures regarding the reporting of inappropriate conduct.

question.text: Organizations unrelated to the University using University owned or leased property must also follow this policy.

Any violations of University policies (including the Child Protection Policy) by an individual will be dealt with in accordance with applicable University policies and procedures, which may include, but are not limited to which of the following:
question.option: Denied permission to continue operation at the University
Immediate suspension pending an investigation or disciplinary actions up to and including termination from the program or University

question.text: Retaliation against anyone acting in good faith who has reported inappropriate conduct in accordance with this policy is considered a violation and must be reported to Human Resources.
Programs that are occasional and need a large number of volunteers may elect to adopt measures and safeguards instead of background checks. Which of the following is a condition of this exception?
question.option: The measures adopted must include requirements that the volunteers be working in public places, not alone with children, and be supervised by a background-checked person.
Programs must compile the names and addresses of the volunteers prior to the event and check the names against the sex offender registry.
Programs must give each applicant a polygraph test.
Programs must provide video surveillance that can monitor the volunteers at all times.
Volunteers must present photo identification to be checked at the event.
Programs must have the approval of the University Child Protection Committee.
